quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 11: Unit 11 Quiz 10
quiz.subtitle: 11.10: Catalysts and Catalysis: Homogeneous and Heterogeneous
quiz.subject: Chemistry

questions.question: Which statement best describes the role of a catalyst in a chemical reaction?
options: It provides a new reaction pathway with a lower activation energy
It increases the total kinetic energy of the reactant molecules
It shifts the equilibrium position to favor the products
It is a reactant that is consumed to produce more heat
questions.explanation: A catalyst lowers the energy barrier ($E_{a}$), allowing more molecules to have successful collisions at a given temperature.

questions.question: What is a 'Homogeneous Catalyst'?
options: A catalyst that exists in the same phase as the reactants
A catalyst that is in a different phase from the reactants
A catalyst that only works in the solid state
A catalyst that is made of the same element as the products
questions.explanation: If the reactants are aqueous and the catalyst is also dissolved in the liquid, the catalysis is considered homogeneous.

questions.question: An example of 'Heterogeneous Catalysis' is:
options: Gaseous exhaust reacting on the surface of a solid platinum catalytic converter
Iodine ions speeding up the decomposition of aqueous hydrogen peroxide
Acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of sugar in water
Enzymes breaking down starch in human saliva
questions.explanation: In a catalytic converter, gas-phase reactants interact with a solid-phase catalyst. This difference in phases defines it as heterogeneous.

questions.question: How can you identify a catalyst in a multi-step reaction mechanism?
options: It is present as a reactant in an early step and reappears as a product in a later step
It is produced in the first step and consumed in the second step
It is the substance with the highest stoichiometric coefficient
It is always a gas, regardless of the other reactants
questions.explanation: Unlike an intermediate (which is made then used), a catalyst is used then remade, resulting in no net consumption.

questions.question: What happens to the Enthalpy change ($\Delta H$) of a reaction when a catalyst is added?
options: It remains unchanged
It decreases (becomes more exothermic)
It increases (becomes more endothermic)
It becomes zero
questions.explanation: Catalysts only affect the kinetics (rate) of the reaction. The energy difference between the initial reactants and final products (thermodynamics) stays the same.

questions.question: The process of a reactant molecule sticking to the surface of a solid catalyst is called:
options: Adsorption
Absorption
Desorption
Activation
questions.explanation: Adsorption is the binding of molecules to a surface, which is the first critical step in heterogeneous catalysis.

questions.question: Why does a catalyst increase the rate constant $k$ in the Arrhenius equation?
options: By decreasing the value of $E_{a}$
By increasing the temperature $T$
By increasing the value of $R$
By decreasing the frequency factor $A$
questions.explanation: Looking at $k = Ae^{-E_{a}/RT}$, as $E_{a}$ gets smaller, the negative exponent becomes less negative, making $k$ larger.

questions.question: What is an 'Enzyme'?
options: A large protein molecule that acts as a biological catalyst
A type of metal used in industrial electrolysis
A reactant that slows down dangerous reactions
A byproduct of incomplete combustion
questions.explanation: Enzymes are highly efficient and specific catalysts found in living organisms.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about a catalyst at the end of a reaction?
options: It is chemically unchanged and can be reused
It has been converted into a product
It has been completely consumed by the reaction
It has changed from a solid to a gas
questions.explanation: One of the defining features of a catalyst is that it is not a reactant in the traditional sense; it emerges from the reaction in its original form.

questions.question: What is 'Catalyst Poisoning'?
options: When a substance binds permanently to a catalyst, making it ineffective
When a catalyst becomes too powerful and causes an explosion
When a catalyst turns into a toxic gas
When the products of a reaction react with the catalyst to form water
questions.explanation: Impurities can sometimes block the active sites on a catalyst surface, preventing the reactants from adsorbing and effectively 'killing' the catalyst's activity.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a complete understanding of how to speed up the world around you.
scoreMessages.70: Great job. You've mastered the concepts of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort. Remember: catalysts lower $E_{a}$ but do not change $\Delta H$.
scoreMessages.0: Review the definition and mechanisms of catalysis.
